comments:
I created a new J2EE dynamic project. The default folders were JavaSource for
Java source and WebContent for html/jsp etc.  Our existing internal standards
and tools require the layout to be ./Source/Java and ./Source/content so I tried
to change my project's preference. I first created these folders, then opened my
preferences. I got an exception below.

In another project, I did not create the Source/content folder and it appears
that Eclipse renamed my WebContent folder. I am running on Windows. If I set the
folder name to Source\Java I got an exception (identical to the one below). If I
set it to Source/Java it succeeded.

David,
The new flexible project contributions will allow users to indicate any source
folder as your web content and will then via the flexible project builder fix
create a .deployables output location which is J2EE compliant.  There are a
bunch of tutorials and api information on this new structure.  It is working now
for a web module but will be expanded for others in the future.  Concerning the
changing of the web content via the preferences page that will be reworked in m4
so i will be pushing this defect to m4.
Thanks

Marked as feature as the properties page for web project as well as preferences
are not available.  Will be added and fixed in M4
Changed Version field given new release numbering.

You can specify webcontent to whatever you like in the .wtpmodules file by 
manually editing it, the tooling will be implemented in M8

I'm not sure how manually editing a metadata file that the user shouldn't ever
constitutes "fixed"....

correction: I'm not sure how manually editing a metadata file that the user
shouldn't ever _see_ constitutes "fixed"....

You could trace the fix for setting the WebContent through defect#102981, this 
defect was maked as closed since the exception mentioned in the defect doesn't 
happen anymore.
